question.content:
The table below shows the volumes of baking soda from several trials of a science experiment. The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ teaspoon.

Volume (teaspoons) | Number of trials
:-: | :-:
$2\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $3$
$3\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $4$
$3\dfrac{1}{8}$ | $2$
$2\dfrac{5}{8}$ | $2$
$3\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $4$
$3\frac{3}{4}$ | $1$

**Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**   
*Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]

hints.content:
The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$. 

Let's number the rest of the number line.


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at two, two and one-eighth, two and one-fourth, two and three-eighths, two and one-half, two and five-eighths, two and three-fourths, two and seven-eighths, three, three and one-eighth, three  and one-fourth, three and three-eighths, three and one-half, three and five-eighths, three and three-fourths, three and seven-eighths, and four. The tick marks at 2, 3 and 4 are emphasized.

hints.content:
The number of trials tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $3$ dots above the value $2\dfrac{1}{2}$ teaspoons.

Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
